{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3352057,"name":"Don ","username":"SudoUser","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/f9ae1b/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T01:42:19.393Z","cooked":"

(Possibly) Hot take: programming in frc is dying and will be a given within the next decade. What I mean by this is every team will have the exact same level of control ability and there will be no advantage to developing a programming subteam, as it will be so abstracted & simple that historically strong control teams will no longer have an advantage.

Although tools like limelight & photonvision are great at making the barrier to entry & accessibility equal for all teams, they make it so teams are no longer rewarded for developing their own solutions. A decade or so in the past control was so important to have, as even a simple vision system was very complicated. This pushed students to learn more about these systems & got them more experience entering future employment.

Now, however, there is no need to innovate or learn new things, as tools like this are standard. I should make it clear I am a huge fan of these tools, not just vision but also path planning and prebuilt swerve code. These smart people are doing great work by making these tools so easy to use for everyone. However, they take away the competitive nature of control and there is no longer any reward for students to learn harder things by making their own system. The same goes for scouting: instead of forcing students to learn and create their own applications in the hopes of gaining a competitive advantage, they can now just use TBA (a great website ) or one of the plethora of other spectacular scouting apps made by other teams.

Control seems to be more and more of an afterthought for teams as tools make it possible for a team to program a simple auto & teleop in less than a week. Sure, certain robots have quirks, such as making the intake not collide with an arm or tuning every mechanism, but these are not huge challenges to students.

On a more optimistic note, by reducing the amount of control members, teams can focus more on the design and fabrication of the robot. Possibly, all members can contribute here and then one or two of the design/fab students will go on to program the robot. This will ensure that a robot is in the field on time. Do you think redirecting control students to design/fab/business will be a good strategy moving forward?

Eventually, I predict ai will take over almost every programming job in the workplace. The “programmers” will just be overseeing the tools and providing the creative spark to generate work. This seems to be the path frc is on as well. It simply feels wrong telling students that programming will be a great field for them to go in to for employment. Provide some insight here, is it important that we keep teaching kids programming even if there may be little job security when they reach the workforce?

Maybe I’m just a pessimistic old guy. Feel free to call me out and tear my argument up! That’s what discussion here is for.

TLDR: While there are still teams out there that have incredible control, the advantage these teams have shrinks every year as control becomes easier and easier, and students learn less and less as more tools become available and make programming easier.

I lead a team without any programming mentors. For the sake of our success, I wish anything you said were true. Please let me know how to close the gap between our programming and the best teams’ without needing to learn anything.

This feels like trolling.

In Team 100 the folks who touch software spend a lot of time in the middle, between code and mechanics, and there’s a backlog of controls initiatives, not a shortage, ranging from full state controls to full auto matches.

I think the days of awesome controls in FRC are just beginning.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T02:08:59.512Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":1570,"readers_count":1569,"score":964.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":33}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":29},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":33,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352077,"name":"Alex","username":"escapedscpcreature","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/escapedscpcreature/{size}/221897_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T02:12:16.210Z","cooked":"

I highly doubt it. We have a team founded in 2019, but our rookie year may as well have been 2022 with COVID. 2022, we only scored a single point. I remember at the start of this season, we were writing out our goals and one of them was “score more than a single point.” Another was “don’t fall over.”

We have about 5 programmers who have been consistently attending meetings since the start of the season, and I don’t think we have more than 10 programmers, period. We’re broke, so we don’t get fancy technology.

Still, we’re number #1 in our state, and our auto EPA is the same as the #10 ranked worldwide team. We used YAGSL, photonvision, pathplanner, etc, but so did teams with notably lower auto EPAs. Even with those libraries, there’s a LOT of work and learning.

YAGSL’s no good if you don’t tune your PID, photonvision’s no good if you don’t get clever with how you use the poses, yadayada.

My main point, even though I went off on a few tangents, is that even if you give someone every tool ever, they still need to know how to use the tools.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T02:12:16.210Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":1477,"readers_count":1476,"score":665.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"Alex","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":20}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63248,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"He/him"},"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/4","custom_user_title":"He/him","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":20}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":20,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352079,"name":"","username":"BadAtProgramming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/858c86/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T02:16:51.937Z","cooked":"

I tend to think that tools provided leave more space for the programming team to do other things. Limelight and PathPlanner made it easier for us to focus on the other parts of the robot, instead of needing to learn everything from the ground up. This year my team’s robot has 3 PID controllers (excluding drivetrain). Last year we had zero.
In my opinion, this will continue to happen. If at some point in the future there is an auto tuning PID program, and full autonomous routine generators, and as you said, everything currently difficult to teams was easy, it would leave more time for the programming team to do other new things, and you would see the best teams with full auto teleop, or other wacky things I can’t even think of.

completely disagree, programming isn’t really something you do on the side. Also i feel like from this point on motors and other electrical components will get so many features that in order to know and master them all you must dedicate quite some time.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T02:33:03.895Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":1095,"readers_count":1094,"score":224.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"Ankur Desai","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61116,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer and Electrical Lead | 2024 Robot Driver"},"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/7","custom_user_title":"Programmer and Electrical Lead | 2024 Robot Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352093,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T02:33:05.712Z","cooked":"

In 1889, Charles H. Duell was the Commissioner of the US Patent Office. He is widely quoted as having stated that the patent office would soon shrink in size, and eventually close, because “Everything that can be invented has been invented.”

My post to Falcon 500 - Too Fancy? in November 2019 also seems relevant:

Falcon 500 - Too Fancy?

This seems like a relevant thread to this discussion from way back in 2010. Preparing CS students for the Robotics Revolution . The article specifically pointed to much higher level concepts being core to robotics that are missing from FRC.

Real robotics involves deep, computationally demanding algorithms. Machine vision, probabilistic localization and navigation, kinematics calculations, grasp and path planning, multi-robot coordination, and human-robot interaction (face tracking, speech and gesture recognition) are core technologies. Today these are found mainly in advanced research labs and graduate-level robotics courses, but they can be made accessible to undergraduates. The time to do that is now.

We’ve seen several of these types of algorithms start to penetrate FRC in the last few years. Team 900 uses high-level ROS components to enable their students to push the boundary of autonomy in FRC. On the other hand, Team 971 emphasizes real time control, kinematics mathematics implementations, etc, and they use every low level technique available to implement high speed control loops that enable their students to push the boundary of what’s possible in the FRC control system. Even though they are polar opposites in approach, I see both of these teams as pushing the state of the art in FRC in different directions, and feel that both are equally inspiring to both their students and other teams.

In development of the WPILib libraries, our approach has been to “raise the floor” by providing off-the-shelf libraries and tools to raise the level of abstraction and make it easier for teams to focus on implementing higher level code relevant to the game challenge. At the same time, we strive to not “lower the ceiling”–we don’t constrain teams to only use the libraries and tools provided (e.g. teams 900 and 971 only use small parts of WPILib).

2020 will bring a host of higher level abstractions to WPILib, as we’re providing much more than just PID control, but also kinematics, odometry, path planning and closed-loop path following (using techniques such as RAMSETE). Will there be teams that choose to reimplement these things themselves to teach the techniques involved? Definitely. Our hope is, however, that there will also be teams that use these abstractions as a base for doing even more advanced autonomous programs or things like machine vision.

I very much doubt teams will stop innovating in FRC. With increasing availability of standard tooling, I see these as not a limiter to upside potential, but rather providing a strong foundation for teams to do even more with the available time. If anything, FRC mechanical design has been the real limiter to doing more with software, and only in the last few years has COTS become sufficiently available to enable teams to start really differentiating software and not just mechanical design. Broadly, I see the current state of FRC software as a dawn, not a sunset, and the coming years will see even more innovation, enabled by AprilTags, a new radio next year, a new more powerful robot controller in 2027, and other things yet to come.

You could be on to something. I suggest you try out your ideas with your team and let us know how it goes.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T02:50:46.383Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":857,"readers_count":856,"score":321.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"Andrew Lawrence","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28413,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Yo! Champ in the making!"},"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/9","custom_user_title":"Yo! Champ in the making!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352109,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T02:53:41.824Z","cooked":"

I do somewhat agree that these prebuilt solutions provide mostly complete good enough solutions to problems in FRC, and have seen that the students don’t truly learn about fundamental robotics principles as a result.

This is how engineering works in general, however. As time goes in, the need for a deep understanding of computer architecture or data structure design goes down as these technologies converge and the best solutions are found.

When someone uses a dictionary in python, do we lament that they might not know how to roll their own hash map? Or even know the principles behind designing a good hashing function?

What I do think is important, however, is that the controls challenges we receive in the games from the GDC continues to increase as well, to give room for teams to elevate their functionality.

And we certainly have that with the centerline notes this year! The best teams in the program are certainly using advanced image recognition to identify which notes are still in the middle of the field, and I’m sure the tippy top teams are even detecting bumpers and tracking opponents to try and beat them to their notes.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T02:53:41.824Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":861,"readers_count":860,"score":277.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/10","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352110,"name":"Arjan","username":"blanck","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/848f3c/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T02:54:00.383Z","cooked":"

I feel as though this seems to be slightly true however for the near future these tools can be improved upon and optimized by top teams or teams willing to put in the extra work e.g in scouting many teams (including mine) still use their own scouting apps inorder to gather more accurate data then the blue alliance can provide.

My point is that for the foreseeable future these tools can be improved upon by teams who are willing.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T02:55:07.630Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":774,"readers_count":773,"score":159.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"Arjan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352113,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T03:06:45.254Z","cooked":"
bathtubed:

When someone uses a dictionary in python, do we lament that they might not know how to roll their own hash map? Or even know the principles behind designing a good hashing function?

At the same time, really understanding how things work under the hood matters a lot when you’re attempting to make something performant. In a theoretical sense you can give someone a bunch of black box complements and they simply need to plumb them together correctly to work, but things rarely work on the first try, and if you really don’t understand what any of the black boxes are doing, you’re going to be stuck debugging for a very, very long time.

It is wild to me how OP and I have such opposite reactions watching FRC over the past 10-15 years. Every year, FRC seems to become more and more of a programming competition. Software (after drive practice) is absolutely one of the biggest performance differentiators between mediocre and good robots. I almost have a bit of nostalgia for the days of FRC being a more mechanically-centric competition at the top end.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T03:06:45.254Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":744,"readers_count":743,"score":538.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"Rahul Yarlagadda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":23}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/12","custom_user_title":"7457 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":23}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":23,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352120,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T03:12:42.064Z","cooked":"

The toolbox is growing, yes.

That is not a reason to continue to invent, seek, and use better tools.

Neither does it imply there is no skill needed to use the tool.

Only a fool looks at a full toolbox and concludes they are skilled.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T03:13:11.351Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":685,"readers_count":684,"score":327.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":12}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352122,"name":"","username":"aven","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aven/{size}/261990_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T03:14:00.957Z","cooked":"

I think that all of these new tech coming along and abstracting away a lot of code will only make teams aim for higher and higher standards. Auto has been a huge decider in matches this year, and if every programming team was on the same level, we’d see a lot of very similar auto EPAs, so there’s definitely still a gap. Additionally, FIRST is probably aware of the advancements in the FRC code libraries, so they’ll probably have their game designs adapt to the new programming standards and still be challenging for software.

Knufire:

It is wild to me how OP and I have such opposite reactions watching FRC over the past 10-15 years. Every year, FRC seems to become more and more of a programming competition. Software (after drive practice) is absolutely one of the biggest performance differentiators between mediocre and good robots. I almost have a bit of nostalgia for the days of FRC being a more mechanically-centric competition at the top end

I was having this very thought the last few days as well. I was thinking back to the first half of the 2010s, and in particular the 469 machines of that era. If you could manipulate the game pieces effectively and drive well, that was usually enough to find some success on the field. Fancy features were for the judges. When 68 did well around that time, that’s definitely the route we were taking.

Fast forward a decade and I think 1648 now is in quite a similar place to 68 then, but the ground has completely shifted under us. Rewatching those older games (sans 2013), even the competitive robots look downright inept by today’s standards. Coming out of auton in a hole that’s equivalent to ~50% of your teleop scoring potential is completely insurmountable. If you’re not winning the programming wars, both in autonomous and in optimization, any success you achieve will be the exception the proves the rule.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T03:34:07.537Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":610,"readers_count":609,"score":667.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"ASmith1675","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":35}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9669,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I don't know what that building is, but I want to build robots there."},"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/17","custom_user_title":"I don't know what that building is, but I want to build robots there.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":35},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":42,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352145,"name":"Andrew Schreiber","username":"Andrew_Schreiber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew_schreiber/{size}/209563_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T03:48:53.137Z","cooked":"

No I will not because you’re 100% right.

You know what happens when you can build on top of basic functionality? You get to work with students on higher level problems. Rather than spending a bunch of time tuning the same dang contour detector to find retro tape we can throw an off the shelf tag detector at it and discuss the tradeoffs that must be made to localize off it. And then discuss how do we fuse odometry with camera pose. And then how do we handle multiple camera poses from different cameras.

Programming in FRC isn’t dying, it’s finally having it’s COTS revolution letting us stop worrying about how to do low level tasks and how to leverage those things to achieve game objectives more efficiently.

I got to have a discussion with a student this year about the difficulties in tracking other robots and the sort of things we need to do in order to do that in a useful way. (It didn’t make it on a robot yet but it’s a space to play with)

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":46,"updated_at":"2024-04-04T03:57:09.767Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":599,"readers_count":598,"score":179.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461262,"topic_slug":"programming-is-dying-frc","display_username":"brandon herr","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":42929,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5847 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/programming-is-dying-frc/461262/19","custom_user_title":"5847 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3352154,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T04:02:31.379Z","cooked":"

I promise you, no matter how good the libraries seem to be there is and always will be room for improvement brought on when called to attention by teams, be it students or mentors.

As for programming dying out, a library is a tool and tools come with user manuals which can be difficult to understand if you don’t know exactly what’s going on.

I expect to be working on Welcome to Yet Another Swerve Document | YAGSL for as long as i work on YAGSL. After only a few months of condensing existing documentation and adding more it’s fast approaching the limits of a brand new programmers ability if they worked on it for 4-6hrs a week.
